pullRequest.title: Psse importer version 33 and 35 (raw and rawx formats)
pullRequest.bodyText:
Please check if the PR fulfills these requirements (please use '[x]' to check the checkboxes, or submit the PR and then click the checkboxes)

 The commit message follows our guidelines
 Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
 Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)

What kind of change does this PR introduce? (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Feature
What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?
Support for PSSE power flow data version 33 and 35 (RAW and RAWX file formats).
PSSE has different data exchange files: power flow, sequence, optimal power flow ... This feature handles only power flow data, but the design has made thinking of potential future support for other files. Common to all these formats is that data sets are defined by record groups. Power flow data has a record group for defining buses, another for loads, ...
RAW is the legacy text format used in PSSE versions prior to 35. RAWX is a JSON-compliant data exchange format that PSSE promotes as the future standard text-based data format for PSSSE. Currently only power flow data has a JSON-compliant format, but it is expected that more PSSE files follow this migration (we would end up having SEQ / SEQX formats for sequence data files, for examples).
The attributes in the PSSE classes can be annotated as valid for specific versions.
Reading and writing the model to the given formats is performed using Jackson and Univocity libraries.
In RAW (legacy text) files the record groups have a fixed order for fields, given in the documentation. Optional fields may be omitted only at the end of each record. A record may consist of multiple lines (for example transformers). Separators for fields in the record could be whitespace or commas. The quote character is a single quote.
In RAWX (JSON)  the record groups are implemented as "Data Table" objects, with names of given fields defined explicitly in a header:
"bus": {
  "fields": ["ibus", "name", "baskv"],
  "data":[
    [101, "Bus1", 500.0],
    [102, "Bus2", 230.0]
  ]
}

nodes.bodyText:
I think that adding the PsseVersionFilter annotation on each subclass of the PsseVersioned is error prone. It seems sufficient to add it once on PsseVersioned.
I'm not a big fan to add annotations that are used only for testing, but I suppose we cannot do anything else.
Could probably be improved by introducing a PsseBranch interface with all the required getters (getI(), getJ(), getK(), getR() and getX())
This method is not used: will you use in a future pull request?
I wonder if we should split this interface in two different interfaces. I think the implementation will result in huge files
I dislike this interface name: I think we should split this interface in two different interfaces.
Could maybe lead to a performance issue: I would implement this using sets, but not sure if it's interesting here
I we can prepare the design for newer version?
Do you forgot something or is planned later? The mapping is filled but not used.
We should extract WindingHeaderTransformer and WindingRatesHeaderTransformer from this class because they are related to I/O
License header is missing

             <groupId>com.univocity</groupId>

nodes.bodyText: Would be more pretty to wrtie PsseVersion.isSupported(rev) or maybe a PsseVersion.checkVersion(rev) method

I don't know if it's recommanded or not to use static initializer. Maybe we can replace by an initialization like this:
private static final Map<Integer, PsseVersion> BY_NUMBER = Arrays.stream(values()).collect(Collectors.toMap(...));
If you follow my advice, maybe the BY_NUMBER map is not needed anymore.

To be discussed: I notice that you create sub classes to support the v35 model. Maybe we should consider to have a single class for both version, but have access to the model version to throw exception when some getters/setters are not available. Something equivalent to what we have in the XIIDM parser
Could it be null?
Replace by a switch case to prepare to support additional versions. The default case should throw an exception
Same remark
Not sure that the super is needed
Why this method is private package and the other one public?
Why this method is private package and the other one public?
Remove the this prefix
Consider toString vs getMessage
Remove extra this prefix
Remove extra this prefix
Same remark
Same remark
Same remark
Same remark
Same remark
As explain previously, I would prefer to throw an exception instead of having a fall back. This would prepare the code for another version.

The name of this variable is not ok: it's more a content than a file. I wonder if it's a good idea to put the content in a string and if it's possible to read the input stream directly. Moreover, the input stream should be closed.
Same remark
Same remark
Same remark
Same remark
Same remark
